review_title: Get Demoted or Lose your Job
pros: In a way you have job security because of the volume of accounts that needs managing.

When that is not enough, you demote the workers and work them more.  In the meantime, the company is buying up other companies.

review_title: Overall, the people make it a great place to work.
pros: Aetna has a staff of very professional and competent people.  I feel that it does an excellent job of weeding out people that might be less than desirable.  Employees are made fully aware of what Aetna's vision for the future is and why things are moving in the direction they are moving.  Ethics are strongly valued and enforced at Aetna.  It is nice to know that people are held to a certain standard that isn't the case in a lot of work places.  And, from what I have seen, it isn't just talk.  People are really held accountable for their actions.
cons: I think that because it is such a large company, it takes a long time for things to get done.  Committee after committee is required to even make a small change.  It can get frustrating at times when you believe that things are being done in a stagnant or less than efficient way.  Additionally, for an insurance company, our insurance costs are extremely high.  I understand that Mr. Williams is trying to set an example for other people, but the high deductibles that go along with our insurance plans can bankrupt those of us who aren't making six figure salaries.

review_title: It was an awesome place to work until they decided that nurses could do everything.

review_title: Decent Place To Work.....If Your Not In The Call Center
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Allentown, PA
pros: Pay, PTO,, Some of the benefits, business casual attire,
cons:
Call Volume- During the interview they did make me aware a of calls being "back to back" but I didn't think that I would be taking close to 140 calls a day. In fact we lost alot of people during our training because of the call volume. They were right about it being "back to back" because you would literally get off one call just take another right after. I think there was one time while I was there, i took 100 calls but that was only because it was holiday and most doctor offices were closed.  What was bad  that you could not even take a break in between calls. I remember being sent  a department email because too many people were taking break between high call volume. Also were were expected to complete off line time work in between calls which was virtually impossible most times as well. The metric system that they expected us to reach was unreasonable and  nearly impossible, As a result, very few people actually received quarterly bonus"s. 

Time Off- Maybe the rest of the company was different but when it came to the call center, time off was near impossible. You couldn't just put in a day for PTO and have it off. Alot of the time there was a  "waiting list" to have certain days off, especially through the months of May and Aug.  If you couldn't get the day off, you would of been forced to just take it off which would you usually result with you getting  what they call an "occurrence".  Too many of these (7 in a 12 month period for your first year) would eventually lead to disciplinary action. All I have to say is if your not too sick and you can still come to work, do so.

Heath Insurance- Don't get me wrong the coverage was great but it was pretty pricey in my opinion.

Advancement: I would say that advancement was there but it was extremely difficult. Alot of people I knew that spent years in that call center environment had no luck getting out and if they did it was because they sought employment elsewhere

job_title: Claims Data Specialist in Bismarck, ND
pros:
Relatively flexible schedule
Paid time off (PTO)
Ability to work through lunches
cons:
I was recently moved from an Aetna team to a Coventry team to aide in the processing of claims for the ACA, Health Exchange. 

The joining of these two companies has been very rocky.  I work in a site where we had both Aetna and Coventry offices and they combined us into one building. We as Aetna employees were instructed to have a positive attitude and make the Coventry employees feel welcome. I can't speak for everyone, but I certainly have done my part to try and make them feel welcome in this new environment. However, since being moved from an Aetna team to a Coventry managed on I can say that my job has taken a job for the worse. 

Prior to my move I processed claims for our Transplant unit and I loved my job. However, I knew that with our merger with the new company that our specialty units would be taking a hit as far as the number of employees went, so when the opportunity came to take a new position on this new team I jumped at it. Boy did I ever make a huge mistake. 

I sit in an area surrounded by former Coventry employees. There are a few that are very nice, but most of them give my team dirty looks and won't answer back if we try to say hi or good morning. Our new management has a serious chip on their shoulder about being bought out and definately takes it out on us, really enforcing what "their" interpretation is of Aetna policy. They've taken away many of the benefits that I've enjoyed in the 6 years that I've worked here as a claims processor, such as a flexible start time and being able to borrow PTO (both of which are still policy in our office, but our new management has chosen not to allow either due to "business" needs.) I can no longer plan on a vacation with my family since I'm not able to borrow PTO and this has caused MANY problems and great upset with the rest of my team. Management also acts like we're supposed to stay two seperate companies and not join into one, which goes against everything we've heard from our CEO, Mark Bertolini. 

I had applied to a position as a trainer a year ago and been accepted, but due to the merger the funding for that position was cut and I did not recieve it. Instead the Coventry trainers are going to be merged into our training program, and based on the trainer we had for our conversion class I shudder to think that these people will be represnting our company.  They were only trained in one very specific area of expertise, yet we in our new positions were supposed to be doing everything. Their trainers had to bring in numerous other people to help in training, and every training course we've had since then has been a farce, since those trainers are only focused on one area. 

The health benefits are a joke.  An insurance company should offer more than two high deductible plans. Even with Aetna putting money into an HSA or HRA you're still paying 100's if not 1000's of dollars out of pocket before Aetna pays anything. I've seen plans by other employers that should really ashame Aetna, since there's no option for a PPO or anything other than a high deductible plan. 

Aetna is constantly talking about the culture of the company as well as the Aetna value wheel.  Upper management definately trots both of these out when it suits them, but pushes them to the background when they need to expedite certain issues. We're supposed to focus on collaboration, innovation, mentoring and coaching, accountability, and service to our members. However, you'll find that commitment varies from site to site and even team to team. 

I do find that I have a very good work/life balance, at least I did before I had to change positions. I find that I can leave this job here and not take it home with me at the end of the day. 

There is also a lot of uncertainty because of the ACA and the Health Exchanges, as well as the numerous layoffs that have just happened in the last week with over 500 people losing their jobs. As much as I've enjoyed working for this company in the past, if things don't improve I will be looking for another job.

Potential to move to other groups.
cons:
The management is horrible.  Absolutely clueless about the business they manage.  They are ruining this company.
The CEO pays lip-service to "values" but nothing more.
Managers are very sneaky and will stab you in the back.

job_title: UM Clinical Consultant in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: Great benefits. 401k w/ 6% company match at hire. Competitive salaries. Potential to work from home if you are friends with your manager.
cons: Poor leadership. A playground for friends to hire friends to hang out and blatantly do as they please. Lack of compassion or flexibility for employees. Undervalued employees. High turn-over.

pros: The people in the trenches are very nice.  Many positions provide the opportunity to telecommute.  Money is provided each year to buy something of your own such as a bicycle or weights that promotes health.
cons: Lack of direction.  The system is in gridlock and changes for customer improvement are very difficult if not impossible.  The billing system is horrific.  The insurance provided to employees is no different than what any other Aetna customer gets.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in High Point, NC
pros:
Flex hours
Work from Home options
Wide array of benefits
Ability to work in a team environment in addition to working independently
cons:
Not much room for advancement in career
High production standards with no margin for errors

pros:
Important responsibilities in a key industry (healthcare)
Dynamic assignments. Not the same work day to day.
Work from home is a huge plus
Good people to work with
cons:
Limited opportunities for advancement within
Slow adaptation to new technologies and processes
Rules / Guidances preventing managers from giving true evaluations to team
Bureaucracy in HR and salary
Limited pay advancement

pros: The pay is the best thing about working for this company.
cons: They no longer care about their employee.  Change is constant however no one is ever on the same page with the changes.  They expect you to do 10 different jobs at once.  Stressful.  They will lie to you just to keep you.  Promotion is more of who you know.

job_title: Claim Benefit Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros: Flexible schedule. Allowed to make up time. Wellness perks and opportunity to earn more to your HSA.  When one department closes they do make every effort to find another job in different departments.
cons: High Deductibles on health plans.  Different departments have different resources.  These should all be the same.  Guessing how to do your work is not fun

pros: Many jobs to choose from.  Telework options are available for some positions.
cons: They don’t promote from within.  Good luck even making it past the HR recruitment team.  The only way you’ll get an interview is if you know someone and they can pull your resume.  Hopefully CVS health’s HR will be more responsive. Many seasoned people were turned down, or not even given an interview because some HR staff member denied their application.

pros: Wish I never left! The management is decent and environment is fairly stable, even though there have been some recent lay-offs. Many people start their careers there and never leave. Pay is slightly lower than the competition, but they offer a MUCH better working environment.
cons: High deductible health plans mean more $ out of your pocket; however, that is getting to be the norm across all corporations.

review_title: Unless you are a minority or a man, you can forget about advancement.
pros:
Decent compensation package.

Relaxed atmosphere.

Great PTO days.
cons:
Being passed over for advancement time and time again in favor of less knowledgable people.

Management doesn't know how to use the programs and systems the employees they manage use, making it difficult to understand jobs and processses. 

Little to no recognition, monetary or otherwise, for doing a good job.

review_title: Aetna consistently provides employees with "tools"  to give best in class customer service.
pros:
Excellent ongoing training of changing healthcare laws. 
Excellent company benefits, wellness programs for employees
Excellent opportunities for advancement or job changes within the company
Excellent work environment 
Excellent ethics
cons: The work is highly regulated, so there is not much opportunity for being "creative" if that is what you are specifically looking for in a company.

pros: Telework opportunities and generous PTO.
cons: The constant layoffs, below industry standard pay, and constant overtime has left its mark.  Employees are taking an increasing amount of medical leave due to the stressful workload and micromanaging of their superiors. The benefits are decreasing every year.  There has been little to no improvement focused at employees in 5 years.

pros:
Telecommute opportunities
Salary a bit more than average
cons:
Frenetic changes in directions based on stock market fluxuations
Major disconnects between areas based on silo goals v. overall company/sector goals
Most fear for job security as Aetna "downsizes" yearly before Year end stockholder reporting to make numbers better--pays out separation only to bring people back on board.

job_title: Care Management Associate in Allentown, PA
pros: Decent pay, reasonable hours, flexible schedules. There are a lot of jobs within the company if you are interested and branching out.
cons: Management is often too busy to handle the needs of the employees. They hire "leads" to handle urgent matters but the leads have no authority and receive no extra pay so they hardly care more than the employees.

pros: Aetna is ahead of the industry in allowing work from home option to its employees. The salary is also competitive.
cons: If you want to be a "champion" of change, this is not the place for you: Aetna is like the "Titanic" of health insurance: It is extremely difficult to lead any sort of positive change because Aetna is "stuck in their ways."

pros: Attempting some interesting innovative efforts.  Work at home perks can be great.  401K matching is good.
cons: Culture is slow and conservative.  Lots of incompetent senior and mid-level leaders.  Always bringing in new executives who last 2 years at best.  Senior level management has little interest in career development of their teams, and little personal interest in their people.

job_title: Member Service Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
-Good supplemental benefits such as schooling and wellness reimbursement.
-Opportunities can be made to grow related skills and network.
-Occasionally events are presented to do paid volunteer events outside of the normal position (though it must be approved pending business needs)
cons:
-Attendance occurrences don't roll off until a year from the time they accrued.
-The position has unrealistic metrics for time and quality.
-Mandatory overtime.

job_title: Public Relations Director in Linthicum, MD
pros: Excellent pay, benefits and work-family flexibility.  Aetna is a company that values diversity, and provides opportunities for all types of people.
cons: Like all health insurers, Aetna is caught up in the uncertainty of the future of the Affordable Care Act.  As health insurance becomes more of a consumer business, Aetna is struggling to adapt to this new reality.

pros: Work at home.  Great 401K match.  Smart people.
cons:
CVS Health changing benefits - however 401K match, longer vesting of stock options, non compete agreements.  High turnover in middle management ranks since there is limited strategy coming from Aetna senior management these days.

Self serving Aetna management talks about mindfulness, but I didn't see it in practice.  

High deductible medical plan.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: Monday-Friday schedules, decent pay, free lunches, quarterly bonuses
cons: Poor training, horrible parking (Must be an employee for 1 year + in order to park in the building garage), high turn over, supervisors don’t know anything, reps are basically telling customers anything to get them off the phones. Supervisors and trainers do not know the job therefore the employees don’t know what they are doing.

pros: Ability to work from home, generous PTO bank, management listens, conservative company that really cares about getting it right the first time.  Nice co-workers.  Senior management and mid-management teams have strong skills.
cons: In the sales team, there isn't a good work/life balance.  Company downsizing in late 2009 and early 2010 has left many departments under-staffed and over-worked.  Health Care Reform legislation has added to the workload of most departments.

review_title: Sure, come to Aetna if you never want to advance
pros: Having a job to pay bills, Telework option for many positions
cons: Very little to no job promotion, most jobs are given to people already known. No one has a fair shot of getting a job because they expect you to know the job before you interview. They like to provide minimal training.

review_title: Help! I'm being bullied by my manager...
pros: The pro is that I am surviving the layoffs that are taking place since the Aetna/Coventry acquisition.
cons: The Cons is unfortunately I will not be able to partake in any of the good benefits Aetna offers its employees because my manager is holding me back from any and every opportunity.

review_title: Hard work and long hrs, depending on the role you have.  Good work/life policies if you can take advantage.
pros: Good policies for flexible work schedules.  Potential for remote work depending on role since Aetna does a lot of conference calls for meetings and has virtual teams.  People are professional.
cons: Depending on work area and role, can be very overworked.   Layoffs are a part of life at Aetna, typically coming every year to two.   As with any large company, there are politics.

pros: Aetna offers its employees Remote Access / Telework opportunities.  Most jobs can be done from any location as long as you have a broadband connection!  Most managers allow their full time employees to telework at least 1-2 days a week.
cons: With the Coventry acquisition, Aetna is downsizing.  They are doing and expecting more with a lot less employees.  It's not about replacing the loyal ones that worked their for many years.  It's about being a lean as possible to keep things going.

pros: A multi-cultural diverse employer and a health insurance-industry leader with a global presence. Work life balance is encouraged, as is healthy lifestyle practice.
cons: Company sometimes pushes its own agenda ahead of customers; ivory tower view of products & system enhancements may fall short of reality and may ignite issues whose resolution maybe slow to realize for the end users as a result of siloed internal channels.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Blue Bell, PA
pros: They are pretty supportive of work at home employees. Decent benefits and time off.
cons: Seem to be known for annually eliminating a lot of positions and those eliminated are not chosen based on their performance.

review_title: Great pay for this field, but little management support or room to grow
pros:
Excellent compensation
Easy to learn and understand performance metrics
cons:
Red tape to make any changes
Conflicting communication from management, changes to program frequent and little support from management
Don't expect to be "heard" - you're just there to do your job

review_title: Great company to work for.  Great work ethics and team mentality.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Columbus, OH
pros: 40 K.  Great pay.  4 day work week.  Manage works with you when you are traveling out of town and need time off.  Supervisors are there for support.  You have places/recourses available to perform your job efficiently.
cons: Not very good health insurance benefits.  Aetna eliminated pension plan for new hires.  Little opportunity for advancement.  Job eliminations at Aetna.

pros:
- Learning the health insurance industry gives you a perspective on the overall healthcare system (healthcare is ~$3 trillion portion of the economy) which will give you good options down the road
- Opportunity to work on a variety of areas within healthcare (clinical, pharmaceutical, wellness, etc.)
- People generally want to do the right thing
cons:
- Rotating carousel of leadership with no institutional memory
- Keeps trying to innovate without the patience to see ideas through

review_title: My manager supports the work I do.
pros: Aetna strives to give work-life balance and the flexibility to be able to work at home. Benefits offered are run of the mill benefits, nothing extraordinary.
cons: Aetna is focused on production, deadlines and do not take into account the work load a person can actually get done in a day; very stressful.

review_title: Management is completely unconcerned with employees , they are unethical in several different areas
pros: Choose the right department and you may be good..weekends off .....Accrue PTO from the first day of employment
cons:
Horrible benefits
Salary is low
No incentives
Training is not good
Time off is difficult

job_title: Claim Benefit Specialist in New Albany, OH
pros: Vision benefits are wonderful! The medical was below standard for the employees. I loved the fact that there was a cafe in the building and plenty of space to store your lunch.
cons: Training was fun but as soon as you are on the floor, it was totally different. I felt like I was confined to my desk, break were very strict, and if you use the bathroom outside of your breaks it's frowned upon. Taking time off is nearly impossible.

pros: Employee oriented programs and ways to help you move up through the organization. Lenient on schedules. Friendly management. Encourages learning of different departments and programs.
cons: Health Insurance benefits are not all that great. Raised min wage standard but others making slightly above that did not receive bump in pay so people who walk in can make same as someone with years experience. Production based environment.

pros: Great mentorship, active intern culture. Aetna really invests a lot into its interns, trying to foster a younger community. Admirable CEO. Through the Chairman's Challenge and multiple volunteer opportunities, many ways to make the most of the experience.
cons: Departments seem isolated. Many people work from home, so lots of floors are mostly empty, sometimes can seem impersonal. Very structured environment.

review_title: Things you should know bfore working for Meritain Health
pros: If you need a job for at least a year, since the turnover is high, there is job security as long as you can do the job with limited training.
cons: Company leadership does not pay based on experience and the company/leadership does not follow their own Aetna corporate guidelines/recommendations regarding pay. Leadership lacks customer service expertise. Leadership does not properly train or assist employees. Leadership only makes suggested improvements if they can take all the credit. Little potential for advancement if not leadership.

pros: As for full time employment, Aetna is an ok place to work.  Benefits are pretty good to ok.
cons: Unrest and unsure of direction company is headed.  Biting off more than they can chew I believe was a mistake and the employees are paying the price in my opinion.

pros:
- Flexible Schedule
- Good and positive culture 
- Work areas entail cubicles and open space work areas
- Has a strong focus on doing things for the right reason, not just profit.
- Comprehensive benefits package (medical, dental, 401k, tuition reimbursement, student loan repayment assistance, EPA, and etc....)
cons:
- Parking in dedicated lots/garage have fees (i feel like you shouldn't have to pay to park where you work).
- Frequent reorganization due to mergers and acquisitions

job_title: RN Care Manager in Charleston, WV
pros: Very good to employees, nice clean office, very reasonable mngt, good supportive staff, work from home opportunity, Monday - Friday, good benefits, opportunity to advance, good office location, treats you like a responsible adult
cons: I have nothing bad to say... good good good good good good good good good good good good good good good good good good good good good

pros: Culture is phenomenal. I'm given a lot of independence, encouragement to come up with unique solutions and senior management regularly supports their direct reports. Get to deal with a lot of unique and difficult problems. Work-life balance is excellent with opportunities to work from home and reasonable PTO allotment.
cons: Large company with a lot of regulation so the usual bureaucracy you would expect from an organization this size. Learning curve is very high

review_title: Overall a good place to work
pros: Overall there were a lot of incentive programs, the benefits were good, apart from the health plans, and the pay in my opinion was great
cons: The health plans are terrible when you consider you're working for the insurance company! They were very cheap, but high deductible so it costs you more in the long run if you go to the doc a lot or have a newborn who is seen often.

pros: Nice opportunities for college grads
cons: Impossible career advancement. Lots of employee fluff and goodies.

review_title: A pretty good place to be
pros:
The overall benefit structure is pretty good.
Ample PTO and biweekly paychecks.
Training program was decent.
Top of the line technology.
cons:
The local management in my office doesn't have a clue about how to run a business. 
Plenty of inappropriate and unprofessional behavior by co-workers. Racist jokes and nude pix are a constant form of amusement for some. 
Favoritism.
High deductible health insurance.

review_title: It's okay if you agree with the companies political views.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in San Diego, CA
pros: The company encourages furthering your education and cross-training in other job titles. A lifestyle of healthy habits gives opportunities to be compensated and lower health insurance premiums.
cons: I don't like the companies political views in my face. I'd received company emails encouraging employees to join their group for political current events & interest. I guess that would be okay if I agreed with their political views.

review_title: Great place to work, only because I worked from home
pros: get to work from home
cons: manager was phony, would say come to me anytime but complain how others were coming to her for advice.

pros: Working from home enables a flexible work environment and less stress environment.  Vacation time is approved when asked.  Zero liability compared to retail or hospital setting.  Work at home allows no commute to and from work.
cons: I really have no cons to this job. Compensation is less than retail but completely worth it when work life balance is given consideration.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Columbus, OH
pros: Pay is good. Coworkers are great. Callers are ok most of the time. Not many supervisor calls.
cons: the systems. the hours and days to work. training department or lack of training department. micromanagement. more concerned with calls stats than taking care of customers. have to type everything into the system because of no automation and it can rack up your after call time. benefits are horrible. all benefits!

pros: like the flexibility of working from home, co-workers are great team players, enjoyed working with the patients. pay is ok however very subjective regarding raises and bounses
cons: Management is top heavy. Management does not encourage all staff to grow in the company only those that they 'hand pick'. Company is too big now with all the merges. It seems it is all about numbers and lost the vision of caring for the patients.

job_title: Claim Benefit Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros: Benefits people integrity values .. Attention to detail, true leadership roll.  Great place to work and be a part of a family
cons: Poor manager, lacks ability to do the job.  Not trained very well. Lacks leadership in daily functions    Shows favoritism  in everything that is done.

job_title: Network Account Manager in Jacksonville, FL
pros: The Pros that I can work from home.  I love being home and  Aetna provides a wealth of information to perform my job duties.   Colleagues are friendly and helpful.  Director very flexible and very interested in my growth.
cons: There really is no Con's to enter.  I'm a new employee and everything looks to be running well within the Team

pros: Good PTO, good team and supervisor, good 401, had Great team leads, flexible schedule, work at home, good communication within team
cons: Lots of changes, disability bought out by Hartford,   The rest of Aetna May go to CVS. Disability dept was only small part of Aetna and not treated with much respect. CSR, lots more changes, not consistent and more and more responsibilities. The pay is not very good. Worked for ten years, learned a lot but time to go. Left in my terms.

pros:
Flexibility 
Other than that I have nothing good to say about this company
cons: Awful Company if you are trying to grow your career, I would not suggest working here. Talent goes unnoticed and there is barely any on boarding/training programs. I regret staying as long as I did. I was told one thing and then management would do another.

job_title: Dental & Vision UW in Hartford, CT
pros:
PTO, 3 weeks in total not including sick time
The pay was good, especially for an entry-level position
cons: Communication could be improved. Almost all the experienced employees worked from home full time, so the Hartford office was a ghost town, at least in my department. Due to the fact that all the senior employees were all working from home, I found it difficult to thrive because there was no face to face interaction.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Houston, TX
pros: Growing company, nice office, custodians are very nice.
cons: Training is lacking in many aspect of the job, benefits are terrible High deductible health insurance then 20% co ins, as of 1/2020 they are decreasing matching 401K to 5% only down from 6%. Overall, due to CVS takeover I would just go with another employer that offers better benefits and is not as corporate driven. They will burn you out with unrealistic stats.

review_title: not bad if you are in the right department
job_title: Precertification Agent in New Orleans, LA
pros: Office environment was great, benefits good, nice incentives
cons: Too much micro managing, 30 mins lunch was nothing, hard to get schedule change, unfair ratings for audits, not enough time allowed for bathroom breaks, bad attitudes from persons who watches your phone times

pros: There are some excellent managers in the organization.  The people you will encounter are generally very nice.  The work life balance is definitely fair.
cons: I did not see a lot of room for growth in the organization I was in.  However, it does not seem that is the case across the board.

review_title: On Display: All Internal and External facets of the Industry
job_title: Account Service Associate in Hartford, CT
pros: Stable company that offers job security and decent salary. Offers complete benefits package: health, dental, life, vision, 401k, pension, stock plan. The specific job position allows one to see all the different dimensions of health insurance, internally, and externally.
cons: Similar to other insurers, health benefits package is surprisingly poor compared to its own clientele. Pay is also below average compared to similar positions at competing insurers.

review_title: Good Company overall. Has changed over the years.
pros: Great coworkers, The office culture is good.  Can work from home many days a week. Good PTO time off and benefits.
cons: Leadership is so so.  The managers should just let people do their jobs. Opportunity to learn new things but you must make the effort.  There is very little formal training offered.  You have to make things happen for yourself.

pros: Excellent management in the IT Learning and Development group. Management seeks input from group members and allows the members to apply their expertise.  In addition, the group VP provides a great working environment.
cons: Senior management tends to over manage the IT Learning and Performance group management. Senior management doesn't understand training and development processes and how they are impacted by number of jobs and time frames.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Shelby, NC
pros: They offer incentives for preventive care.
cons: The office in this location is small and there is no room to grow.  The supervisors have favorites.  The encourage you to speak up and identify inconsistencies or incorrect actions but, when you do it is downplayed or discredited.

pros: There are no pros because the good things that we did have got taken away, for example 25+ years, got a weeks vacation taken away. Pros?  I think not.
cons: No work/ life balance. Management thinks they can bully you to do more work in less hours. Team leads don't respond to anything you have to say to try and make things better. It's their way or no way. I would not recommend working at Aetna to anyone. Stress level is off the chart.

pros:
Positive culture - people are nice to each other and morale is high on my team
Work from home opportunities
Great benefits and focus on healthy employees
Opportunities for professional growth and career advancement
cons:
Very large company, so on occasion difficult to find answers or resources, but eventually do. 
National focus which can sometimes dilute local market advantages and messaging.

pros: Bonuses and team potlucks. Food trucks for lunch. Decent health benefits that are based on sliding scale income. Close to central Ohio in terms of commuting.
cons: Chained to desk. Constantly monitored.

pros: Good training and good pto time bank allows for time off. Raises are based on merit and come quite often if you are producing.
cons: Management expects results almost immediately when you come out of training, this is not always possible as the job takes at least 6 months to get used to.

pros: Aetna is a great company to work for, with overall good benefits except for Medical. The management team is great!
cons:
For medical benefits they offer an  HSA where you pay most of the stuff out of pocket. They also offer 
lower then market pay using the health benefits as a carrott but its not really that good.

review_title: Great company, but not great middle managers
pros: Aetna is a great company to work for. It offers its employees great benefits; however, many employees are not aware of all that is offered to them. They may have to dig a bit to learn of what is available.
cons: Many of the middle managers at Aetna do not support their employees. Rather, they are in it for themselves and will throw their employees under the bus.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: Adequate salary considering what is required to do the job, restrooms are clean, people are pleasant and burned out.
cons: Lack of satisfaction has created an overturn, along with employees being lent out to other departments, makes a shortage and representatives taking upwards of 80 calls a day. Employees feels robotic and lacking fulfillment.

review_title: Good benefits, but work with lots of contractors remotely.
job_title: Applications Developer II in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
- Good Benefits (nice bonus, and 401k matching)
- Ability to work remotely
- Encourages moving around in the company.
cons:
- They use a lot of contractors in IT, and working with them can be difficult.
- Didn't feel a very sense of team with everyone working so remotely.
- So much enterprise software you're constrained by.
- Very paranoid, expect to not be able to use a lot of useful sites if you come into work.

review_title: They have no idea what's going on
pros:
They increased salaries to a minimum of $16/hr for people in customer service. 
The big wigs are very nice and hold conferences for all employees to share information.
cons: When it comes to IT, they have no idea what's going on. projects are created and they work for a month and then change what they're doing so you have to start at square one.

job_title: RN Utilization Nurse Consultant in Harrisburg, PA
pros: Great work environment, position allows for great work and life balance, pay slightly above industry standards. ability to work from home, on-boarding is self directed but are clear on where you should be / goals. Everyone is friendly, tuition reimbursement is ok, great reimbursement for gym membership, cafeteria onsite
cons: Some on-boarding task / training require self motivation / discovery. A lot of telework makes training new staff tough at times.

job_title: Medical Underwriting Consultant in Hartford, CT
pros: Good Coworkers and Managers, Work-life balance (in regards to work-at-home and ability to take vacation or time away). Great amenities at the Corporate location (Gym, great cafeteria).  Executive Leadership and Management is strong.
cons: Below Industry Compensation (this may be partial due to the value from Working at Home).  Underwriting Department is not respected within the corporation.

review_title: Aetna is okay, my department is a mess
job_title: Senior Claim Benefit Specialist in Hartford, CT
pros: Job oppurtunity and job security
cons: Health benefits, training, length of time you have to wait to move on to another position

pros:
Flexible Sch. Was allowed to telecommute
Great Co-workers and Managers
PTO benefits are great and the HR system was easy to use
cons:
Pay is subpar to the industry
Promotions are linked with others rather than own merit
There are not that many opportunities for different career changes unless you are located in Connecticut.

pros:
Opportunities for advancement in proportion to your willingness to work for it
Good training program
Great wellness programs
Aetna Values are actually put into practice, not just given lip service
cons:
Change happens quickly and the front line isn't always made aware
Work/Life balance gets a lot of talk time, but there isn't a lot of follow-through

pros: Flex schedule, LOVE my supervisor, really like my team (most of the time), feel like I am using my BSN, autonomy, love my patients. Ethical company. Just a great department to work for.
cons: Work overload (but that is everywhere). Took a long time to get into the company (4 to 6 months). Some departments are not as good as mine (so I heard). Management is overwhelmed. It is almost imposible to move up the corprate ladder and make a decent salary.

review_title: Great company on the cutting edge of invoking change in healthcare.
pros:
-Excellent company that inspires change. 
-Great growth opportunities. 
-Senior management is transparent and caring. 
-Everyone values our customers and does the right things for the right reasons.
cons: -Workload in the current environment is too busy.

review_title: The hammer came down last week.  I'm laid off.
pros: The paychecks didn't bounce.  I was allowed to telecommute.  I had one co-worker who I could relate to and they lived back East.
cons: I had nothing to do most of the time.  My manager was the worst one I've had in my entire career of 45 years.  Worst health insurance I've ever had as an employee.  I have tons of experience but was assigned jobs that a staff assistant could do.  My talent was basically wasted and I blame management.

pros: Telecommute opportunity, flexible start times, good employees to work with, good salary, employee incentives, clean working environment
cons: High deductible plans, hard to get another position internally, no clear cut direction, sometimes very little work available, layoffs every year, people act too busy to help you so be prepared to learn things on your own time

review_title: Very pleasant people to work with!
pros: Mark's take on family time being very important and taking PTO.
cons: Not enough work station space for new hires and that may leave a bad first impression on the company as a whole. No toilet seat covers or bathroom deodorizers in place!

job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Blue Bell, PA
pros: Very flexible work environment - a lot of work-from-home possibilities.  Co-workers are mostly great people who care about the jobs they do.
cons: They reorganize and change direction constantly, which usually involves layoffs.  Very few opportunities for advancement, at least in IT.  They don't care about doing things correctly, they just want to do it as cheaply as possible.

review_title: Not a lot of internal advancement opportunity
job_title: Claim Benefit Specialist in Tampa, FL
pros: For the most part a good place to work, flexible schedules and pay is decent. Never had a problem with co-workers or upper management.
cons: Very hard to advance within the company! Management sometimes worry's more about numbers than their employees or processes. Health Insurance is not great, very high out of pocket costs.

pros: Diverse community, flexible work arrangements, forward thinking CEO.
cons: Constant reorganizations, lack of promotional opportunities, department leaders too busy to foster   employee growth or to help determine best fit.

job_title: Applications Technology Leader in Downers Grove, IL
pros: Great place to work when one has the actual job. However, one can be hired one month and be laid off by the end of the year.
cons: They lay-off people no matter what your "review" is. It's all about the stock price. They hire one month, then lay-off the next.

review_title: A decent place to grow old with
pros: The PTO is great! Management is very flexible with your schedule. No micromanagement at least not in my team.  Extremely stable. Co-worker are very friendly.
cons: no professional growth, no personal growth, lack of morale, a lot of unneccessary politic. They have a boy club... not good at all. Some manager don't back up their team. Very disorganized, lack of communication between department, therefore, very inefficient

review_title: Innovative and collaborative environment, tough work-life balance
pros:
* very innovative and forward thinking leadership team
* strong identification with, and adherance to, company values
* integrity of leadership and general employee population
* collaborative environment - if you don't cooperate, you won't be successful
* inspiring vision (desire to be the very best in the industry worldwide)
cons:
* tough to maintain work-life balance; management encourages it, but does not effectively role model it
* health benefits not as competitive as they could be
* high pressure, metrics driven environment

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: Over time available (although sometimes mandatory),
cons: When Aetna purchased Coventry there were many organizational changes. Instead of hiring staff that was needed to fill the new departments they moved around the current staff. This meant there was never adequate coverage at any given time. Of course when this happens, customer service is less than stellar and employees quickly become burned out.

pros: Great place to work. Benefits are ok. Salary is exceptional and more than expected. Lots of opportunities to move up in company.
cons: Interviews took too long. Had to talk to5 different people. When I was told I had the job, I found out later I had to do another interview.

pros: Work at Home, Great pay with a BSW; opportunity for growth
cons: Although the pay is great for someone with a BSW, you are ultimately overworked. Also, consistency is non-existent. Every week or so, there is a different process which makes it difficult remember all the changes. There is somewhat of a racial division. Every race seems to only talk to their own which isn't good in a work environment.

job_title: MBU After Hours in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great managers. Fun people who are really friendly. Wonderful atmosphere but they can be really personal sometimes. Training is easy. Systems are easy to navigate and call stats are easy to maintain. Great place to work
cons: Schedules don't change. You need to be ready to have a set schedule with no choice to change for a very long time

review_title: It's okay but could be better
pros: Great benefits, good pay, ability to work at home with minimal trips into home office. Yearly bonus and extra merit bonus as well.
cons: Long work hours, expected to work over 8 hours to 'get the job done' due to salaried status. Too many meetings.

job_title: Customer Service Specialist in Orlando, FL
pros: Opportunity for development and growth
cons: Encouraging off-the-clock work by emailing urgent requests, frantically calling your employees, or texting them after hours only increases your liability in an FLSA lawsuit. Many times employees are stressed trying to meet their quotas and will spend extra time off the clock to work orders and tasks. Management is aware of after-hours work which often include emails and texts, he or she should make sure the employee is compensated for their time and they don’t.

job_title: Quality Analyst WAH in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The environment is employee friendly and the employees are tremendous. They are encouraging of "Work at Home" positions, with 20-30 % of the employees doing so by 2014.
cons: They outsourced the Pharmacy Benefit Manager division, so pharmacy jobs are very limited at Aetna, but the  Medical and Life insurance departments are growing!

review_title: first couple years OK but got unbearable
pros: There are some talented people at Aetna but many are leaving for good reasons.  I enjoyed working with my immediate supervisor.
cons: Aetna was an OK place to work for the first 2 years of my career there.  More recently, there was WAY too much work for the number of people on my team but management refused to hire despite great revenue and earnings.  Making a decision (i.e., needing multiple layers of managment to make it for you) is a painfully slow, inefficient, ambiguous process.

pros: Great company, great pay, get annual bonus based on performance. Work from home with flexible schedule. Good work/life balance. Get other perks of tons of vacation days, tuition reimbursement, money reward/incentive for participating in healthy lifestyle programs. Work is never boring.
cons: Can be too fast paced at times since it is a production environment with high expectations.

pros: Ability to work from home; decent salary
cons: Constant lay-offs due to reorganization and outsourcing of jobs. Frustrating to have to reprocess claims due to inaccurate processing by overseas processors....and then be job eliminated after 15 years. Focus now is on quantity, not quality.

job_title: Network Manager in New York, NY
pros: Comprehensive benefits and very fair compensation.
cons: The national Medicaid contracts group had some toxic blood, unsupportive management and managers, to say the least. Poorly led by senior managers who were rough around around the edges and more like used car salesmen than professionals seeking to lead by example.

pros: Visionary leader who is smartest person in room, knows where to take company
cons: Not sure the organization success is sustainable.  CEO master of projecting a "healthy" work environment to press and the "mass" internal employee population. But there is much dysfunction and back stabbing at the top which has led to many unfortunate leadership departures including the well respected newly appointed Head of HR who left after 2 weeks on the job.  This is not a good sign.

review_title: I went from loving it to having to run from it to keep my sanity.
pros: Pay and benefits. You don't have to be crazy to work there they'll train you. (Saw it on a t-shirt) haha
cons: Poor leadership, can take an expert back to feeling like a novice, destroyed confidence and self esteem.

pros: They offer competitive benefits and longer than normal paid time off. They respect employees and value diversity, have good on-the-job training, and reimburse for certain training, schooling, and certification.
cons: Many jobs can have low level ceilings, meaning career directions may only have 2-3 levels to them and then you need to change career paths. Then the way they measure your aptitude for one job may be based on the built-in competencies of your current job description.

pros: There are times of downtime followed by times of chaos.
cons: Very political and left-wing culture. The CEO used to be a cheerleader for Hillary at meetings. Very little actually gets done. Lots of wasted time and downtime.

review_title: Not a bad place to work
pros: Company values are excellent in regard to community health and the effort of its employees
cons: Office setting is very segmented

job_title: Member Service Representative in Houston, TX
pros: Thorough training with competent staff managers are empowering  and knowledgeable. The company genuinely cares about their members and employees .. benefits are great pay is competitive  bonuses are easy to get because the metrics are reasonable avg 400-1200 quarterly.
cons: Nothing out of the normal. Some teams are busier than others taking planned time off can be nearly impossible for some during peak season.

pros: work at home; annual bonus, paid time off that can be used for vacation and sick time; flex work schedule; promotes volunteerism
cons: few opportunities for certified project managers; white tower mentality; sacred cow mentality; disconnect between IT and business; tight on budget; anticipate job eliminations at end of year

review_title: Leadrship does not walk the talk-employees are not valued
pros: some work at home opportunities depending on the division you work in; business casual; 401 match is great
cons: No HR support; Inadequate orientation; constant  turmoil-crisis management; leadership not interested in true quality process improvement; poor employee health insurance; technical capabilities at a level lower than expected for an international company;

review_title: Information technology departments run on the good ol' boy network.
pros: Salary was reasonable and benefits were acceptable. Job responsibilities were mostly as expected.
cons: If you're not part of the internal good ol boy network it is hard to get promotions.   Those who are,  well get promoted whether capable of doing the job or not.

review_title: Great location , but no room to grow with degree
pros: Great incentives on health, culture advocates , Give to community such as Health Fair
cons: No room to grow especially with a degree, Management doesn't listen to advice from employees, all about the numbers, pay not very good

pros: The company provides a technology to effectively work from home. I worked with high caliber, talented peers in a very interesting line of work.
cons: Very hierarchal, probably not the best fit if you like to move quickly and are entrepreneur.

review_title: Love my job and love Aetna
pros: Sounds corny, but the people are the greatest asset of the company.  Every enterprise has opportunities for improvement but I would say Aetna is rich in human capital.  I believe we sincerely care about the customers we serve.
cons: It's a very large company and there are always issues related to agility and siloing.  Also, legacy systems can be challenging.

pros: Coworkers are like family members and everyone is willing to help you with the processes of enrolling members into various health plans
cons: Management sometimes kept you in the dark about what is going on within the company and you were not allowed to participate in company meetings

pros: Great rank and file, Excellent benefits. Overall a wonderful place to work.
cons: Stale middle management that doesn't always mirror what upper management sees as core focus for the future. As with all companies this size, watch out for office politics.

job_title: Underwriting Consultant in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: it is a good place to start and build skills and then go to another carrier or another job that pays better and has better benefits.
cons: pay and benefits are pretty poor and they tend to keep them pretty low especially with CVS taking over.   The hours are also very demanding with over 60+hrs a week for over half the year once you are salaried and at least 40+ hours the rest of the year

pros: They truly value their employees.  Aetna and the employees truly live by a set of core values and walk the walk, every day.
cons: It is really one of the best places I have ever worked.  If I had one complaint, it would be that the benefits are a bit expensive.

pros: Great benefits, above average pay, great people, open door managers policy. Ability to work from home when needed is a huge advantage
cons: Even though promotions come from within, they don't happen early or often. Need to stand out in order to reach your potential.

pros: Aetna promotes work-at-home and understands that it's not just a perk for employees, but a way to retain talented employees.
cons: Many positions were transferred to CVS Caremark, a company which does NOT promote or understand work-at-home or even work/life balance.

pros:
Work from home opportunities 
Nice people
cons: In my opinion, If you work from home, you open yourself up to the possibility of being downsized. Being in a virtual environment makes it challenging to have exposure to leadership/decision makers, due to the company rarely having face to face team meetings. Additionally, people frequently get downsized, leadership is poor and job opportunities are limited. Several people were stuck in the same role for multiple years, due to new opportunities being non-existent.

review_title: Great company just don't get laid off
job_title: Customer Service/Provider Helpline Quality Analyst in Pompano Beach, FL
pros: Excellent benefits that kick in the first day of work. PTO starts as soon as your first day. The overall feel of the company is that they care for you and your family. Great end of year or quarterly bonuses.
cons: Management was never upfront with changes. You get black balled if you get laid off, it seems like you can never work for the company again.

job_title: Behavioral Health Customer Service Representative in Sandy, UT
pros: The co workers, bonuses, healthy lifestyle incentives.  Aetna has a great tuition reimbursement plan.  Great benefits starting day one. Option to work from home if earned.
cons: Disorganized at times, especially with training. Upper management seemed out of touch with departments they were in directly in charge of.

pros: Excellent technical environment which is constantly upgrading. Very employee friendly work system which allows balance between personal and professional life.
cons: Corporate decision are sometime seem to have short term future goals and not long term overview of growth which in tern leads to business centric model from its current consumer centric model with employee interest at hand

pros: Large company with good benefits. Decent PTO policy. Salary plus bonus. Healthy lifestyle incentives and wellness credits annually.
cons: High performance culture that can lead to burn-out if employee is not careful to observe work-life balance. Company does stress importance of work-life balance but work loads are at times too high to avoid working a lot of hours.

pros: Salary, bonuses, casual dress, work from home opportunity.
cons:
If you're assigned to Coventry contracts, you're forgotten. They tend to only work on improving procedures on the Aetna side and promote employees on Aetna contracts.

Working holidays and weekends.

job_title: Registered Nurse Case Manager in Blue Bell, PA
pros: Benefits are ok, compensation is ok - on paper, I love my nurse colleagues
cons: It’s all about the numbers - weighted productivity and metrics - however, they won’t disclose what the weighted productivity is based on! I have NEVER worked for an employer who will not disclose what they “grade” you on or what each task you perform is worth...... Aetna does not care about their members and outcomes, they only care about the “numbers” and what their reports generate! Nursing DOES NOT always fit into a box..... There is no transparency with this job and the expectation is kept secret! Upper management is invisible and direct supervisors have their hands tied. This culture is toxic and not the least bit supportive. Now they are requiring multi-state licensure for their nurses and they expect this extremely time consuming task to be done on your own free time! The salary appears fair on paper, but when you are threaten by your managers to complete the task of obtaining 25 extra state licenses without any time allotted during your work day - your compensation is pathetic! Total bait and switch!! Extensive training that really doesn’t prepare you for your job! The senior administrative assistant is just down right nasty!!  The computer programs are bulky, cumbersome and not user friendly - built for reporting only and there are known glitches that really don’t capture everything you do and they are aware of it but your still held accountable! Just buying time......and then I’ll most likely move on to a better company such as Accolade, BC/BS, etc..... Maybe it’s a good thing that they are being bought by CVS........

pros: Great work environment, great coworkers, generous merit and bonus if you work hard
cons: Many changes often with little notice to implement. You have to always be ready to readjust. If you don’t deal well with change, this is not the company for you.

pros: They pay well, but the cost is your conscience
cons: Explaining to insured people why Aetna won't cover what the doctor says they need.   Having every doctors office calling to complain because they haven't been paid in 90 days.  Worrying if you were going to get a subpoena every day you went to work.    Our system would report to a provider that someone had coverage then months later it would be determined they had no coverage and we had to collect from a doctor who already performed services, including surgeries, that we were then saying weren't covered.

pros:
-Good experience
-A capstone project for all interns
-Networking events with other interns and employees
-Looks good on your resume
cons:
-Programmers are offshore
-Didn't learn too much during the internship.
-Projects were trivial, not too related to the team.
-Team doesn't really care about you as the intern (they have more important tasks than helping you) except for your manager

pros: Employee benefits are good. The overall culture of the company is great.
cons: Current opportunities for advancement are minimal.

pros: All around very professional.  Excellent employees who share their time and talent.  Great medical, dental, vision, etc. benefit package.  Aetna really is the best in the business.
cons: Outsourcing of jobs which leads to layoffs.

job_title: Bilingual Customer Service in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Good pay, Professional work enviroment,  Always taking 1 hour weekly updates  in training, regarding State laws and company's E-policies, in order to give the good service to members.  If employee manage to get good Quality reviews,  get pay a Bonus every 3 months.
cons: Terrible Health Insurance benefits to employees.

pros: Nice building and plenty of parking spaces. Hour long lunches.
cons: More meetings and games than work. It is not okay to be heterosexual here. They prefer the diverse talent rather than talent that actually works. They do lay offs or end of contract at Christmas. Get new managers the ones you have are awful. They are heartless and do not connect with staff. Cold miserable leaders do not inspire others!!! Overtime when managers are not present is a free for all. They think something is wrong with you if you work instead of play during weekend work.

review_title: Your success depends on if you work for "Aetna" or "Coventry"
pros: Great internal training and the entire hourly staff recently received a pay increase to $16/hour.
cons: Management needs to let go of old ways and move forward with upcoming changes if they want to succeed in a competitive healthcare market.

review_title: Allows rules and policies and laws to be broken
pros: It was a paycheck with great benefits and they had a gym and cafeteria..
cons: Management for claims has poor professionlism and never talks to you unless she likes you... Supervisor is the same way she can walk right pass you and not speak but will speak to your neighbors..

review_title: Exciting opportunity within a large company
pros: I worked for Aetna for over 20 years.  It is a great company to move up in.  I gained lots of knowledge and experience.
cons: Honestly I don't have any cons.  The only con was that it was a long drive to the office. However , I ended up by working at home the last 3 years of my employment which ended up being a pro.

pros: Depending on team, they offer good work life balance large organization with internal opportunities, variety of products provide excellent experience good 401k
cons: Potentially taking away flexibility, insurance benefits are actually pretty lacking with mostly high deductible plans.  Co workers allowed to mistreat peers

pros: Employee programs and coffee shop on site. Good 401k match. Decent healthcare options. That is about it really. Likable CEO
cons: Only work from home if you are a chosen few. Prides itself on openness and inclusion, but that's only if you agree with them (left). Extremely biased and one sided. Micro management is common.

pros: Work from home opportunities, salary, bonus program, varied & sometimes interesting work, good work/life balance
cons: Executive management out of touch with real world IT,  micro-management of billable project time, very difficult to get promoted despite (repeated) favorable performance reviews.

pros: Very flexible for PTO and working at home
cons: They don't replace staff that leaves and it makes the stress unbearable for those who remain. It made it almost impossible to keep up with the workload and service customers as well as I would have liked to. There was just not enough time in the day.

job_title: Provider Relations Representative in Overland Park, KS
pros: I am paid well and bonus structure is generous.
cons: No work life balance, all over the place and the changes are not taking into account the time it takes to research the root cause of claims issues so work is overwhelming.

review_title: Couldn’t wait to get out of there
pros:
Work from home
Home life balance
cons:
Terrible decisions made by upper management. 

They never listened to our suggestions 

Training was a joke

They expected you to know how to handle situations that you’ve NEVER been trained on

Raises were terrible. I worked there 10 years and never made it to $40,000 a year

job_title: Senior IT Portfolio Manager in Hartford, CT
pros:
Leader in health insurance
Proactive role in the healthcare debate
Knowledgeable Managament
cons:
Employees are treated more as an expense then an asset. Philosophy towards employees seems to be "ride the horse until it drops, then get another horse".
In many cases, the health benefits for employees are less than those of Aetna clients. You would think there would be some advantage for working at Aetna. Even retail companies give employee discounts.

pros: Aetna is generally a good place to work.  Everyone really does work hard working and the management has a decent direction.
cons: The benefits are not the best.  Stress level is generally high and even though the company supports work/life balance, you don’t always get it.

review_title: An average company to work for
pros: Teleworker-friendly. Nice amenities at HQ. Decent benefits. Corporate integrity. Trying to be on cutting edge of healthcare changes. Welcoming to young, college-educated workers. Friendly to LGBT.
cons: All depts. are under-staffed.  Cost-cutting and down-sizing is a constant way of life.  Not friendly to older workers.  Difficult to get promoted unless you work at HQ.

review_title: Overall a good place to work
job_title: Claim Benefit Specialist in Fresno, CA
pros: Large portion of the workforce are work at home, very flexible hours and very relaxed dress code, with a few exceptions employees are allowed to manage their workload in whatever way works best for them.
cons: Work at home program currently on hold...good luck getting approval to go home if you aren't already there. Repetitive work that can get old after a while. Constant reshuffling of management and workforce structure.

review_title: Always room to grow, but rapid growth is often limited
job_title: Network Account Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Always room to grow, PTO opportunities are readily available, plenty of volunteering opportunities, most managers listen to employees.
cons: Pay increases can be slow in coming and limited when you transfer between positions [salary increase cap] and new hires make more than transferring employees.

pros: Work from home opportunities. Good people. Great managers.
cons: Salary. The company increased hourly wages to a minimum of $16. It bothers me that now for a person with a degree in a position that requires a degree and I make just a couple dollars more. Bonus. We constantly hear how great the company is doing and yet our bonus doesnt reflect it. Removing overtime opportunities when we make more in overtime than we do in bonuses.

review_title: Like the job not the managers
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Pay is decent, time off is decent job is challenging. Mostly positive experience if you don't need the health insurance offered
cons: Managers micromanage, berate, embarrass and threaten. They are not supportive. CEO just cares about the profits and not the employees

job_title: Member Service Representative in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Benefits, 50%match 401k, generous PTO, Quarterly bonuses, low premiums for health insurance.
cons: Micro management, always difficult to use PTO due to "business  needs." Unable to get full week off for vacation. Extremely difficult to advance to another position within the company.

pros: Work at home; flexible schedule; reasonable benefits; can be a good place if you find the right insulated environment - they are few and far between.
cons: Clueless senior management; no job security; organization in constant flux; very tight with $$; employees are not valued contrary to company rhetoric.

pros: Worked at home. Great interactions with members and full life span Case management.  User friendly software to maintain inclusive healthcare records
cons: Hi volume productivity required. Frequent changes in workflow and documentation creates difficulty to meet NCQA and PG requirements.  Assignment changes without employee input.

pros: Aetna has taught myself to work independently in a quiet environment as well as having a great team to assist in any way.
cons: The extreme need to at least have one dependable Floor Manager to assist the flow of the team daily.

pros: Great vacation time once you’ve been there for a number of years. Great wellness incentives
cons: Lots of favoritism, lots of people who can’t be bothered to help anyone out.

pros: Flexibility, benefits, WAH opportunity for some
cons: No work life balance, demands are endless, not paid enough for their expectations, expectations are not realistic

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: It is only a paycheck.
cons: Total lack of consistency.  The benefits are mediocre.  Ask for help or make a request and depending on your supervisor you may or may not get a response in a timely manner.

review_title: A great company to work for
job_title: Usability Experience Lead in Hartford, CT
pros: change careers and still remain with the same company.  easy to network. team work is a vital tool.  the people who work here are fabulous.  Teleworking is a huge possibility.
cons: future can be unknown and scary.  Once you find a position you like, it's difficult to get higher raises.

pros: Started out with a great manager, decent time off, cross-training opportunities always available.
cons: Benefits are a joke for an insurance company, high turn over, poor morale on staff, bloated middle management.

review_title: I used to like working for Aetna
pros: Work time is flexible and the amount of vacation time we get is good.
cons: Department management is far removed from the needs of the employees. My department is a stressful environment where we are overworked and understaffed. Complaint and appeal analysts are resigning because of the work environment and management is not replacing them.

pros: Many dedicated, hard-working employees both at headquarters and at sites around the country; telework opportunities are offered; company does lots of volunteer work and the Aetna Foundation provides many community grants; most people live the Aetna values everyday.
cons: Too many department reorganizations and manager turnovers; more career development opportunities needed; benefits can be costly; some areas have too many managers, not enough worker bees; many departments are siloed, even those that should be working together.

pros: The pay. The job is what you make it, a call center is a call center; if you choose to go to work and do your work you will fair well. If you choose to participate in office gossip, you will have your fair share of issues. There is a cafeteria on site that offers food throughout the day. That's a plus!
cons: Endless calls. Open enrollment. Catty co-workers. Childish co-workers. Childish managers.

pros: Aetna allows lots of flexibility in work arrangements.  They have a large number of staff that work from home.  It makes work life balance easier
cons: Diverse opinions are not encouraged.  You have to be careful what you say.  Others are not very polite when disagreeing with you.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Leadership, growth, visionary, progressive, focused on employees their growth, health and building a healthier world . Innovative, challenging and growth.
cons: There is a hard time to find work life balance, expectations are very high but they reward if met.  Need more programs to provide future leaders exposure to other areas of the business.

pros: Support and Encouraged healthy life style with healthy benefit points and dollars to pay for healthy purchases, such as bicycles, attheletic shoes, gym membership, Aplle watch, and the likes.
cons: Demanding work schedule, excessive multitasking, unlear responsibility allocations to the proper individuals, excessive expectations, salaries are not as fairly distributed to the everyday workers.

pros: I received excellent training and acquired much industry knowledge at Aetna.There are great opportunities for advancement if you apply yourself. The company does a great job with diversity.
cons: There can be some nepotism and favoritism shown in certain departments. The company has become more focused on the business aspect of healthcare but this is true of the industry as a whole.

review_title: Solid company and inspiring leaders; a bit political
pros:
-Solid company vision, mission
-Inspiring leaders (especially Bertolini) have a bold vision
-Willing to invest in next-generation healthcare ideas
-Very friendly/collegial atmosphere
-They invest heavily in training
cons:
-Like any big company, quarterly earnings can stifle progress on more interesting game-changers
-Lots of turnover at senior levels, and most senior people tend to come from outside the company, so opportunity for advancement at very senior levels is tricky

job_title: Senior Information Security Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Work from home  with slightly better than average salary. Able to be flexible with hours if you have appointments.
cons: Very poor to non-existent management support. Other worldly expectations and two years zero raise.

pros: Aetna cares about the members well-being. They want the best for the member and strive for excellence. They are a top notch Company.
cons: My viewpoint is the Employee strives for excellence and to give someone a chance to become the best and stay on top and if that means they need help than provide this the Employee is worth it at all times.

pros: Some departments will allow a few high performing employees to work from home.  Everyone comes into the door making no less than $16 an hour
cons: Poor Management. They will lie to you about being able to move up. You have to let your supervisor know when you apply to another position. They can block you from moving.

review_title: Worked with a team of great nurses who were always happy to share there knowledge and lend a hand.
pros: Good vision for changes they are making with Healthcare.  Many work from home opportunities, no weekends or holidays, generous PTO
cons: It is such a large company and very difficult To get information from human resources or payroll when you need to speak with someone.  Supervisors try to help but is difficult for them to get the information also

pros: Generally flexible with work schedule where possible.  Good salary and benefits.  Great coworkers with a strong sense of mutual team support and good at encouraging professional development.
cons: Releases could be a bear.  They happened on weekends and would often bleed into the following week, disrupting the early sprints within the following release.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Blue Bell, PA
pros: The other case managers are nice to work with, but the turnover is high, so that doesn’t matter. There is a good tuition reimbursement and benefit perks but you’ll never know about it because it requires you to dig through layers and layers of webpages with no direction and no time to figure it out.
cons: The supervisors and managers are not well trained in leadership and management and take on more of a dictator role with their employees. They listen to every call you make and even when you think you have crossed your T’s and dotted your i’s, they are going to criticize you, and hold a meeting about it, which means there goes your lunch. The criticism is not constructive. You are simply never good enough. They do a great job breaking you down but never build you back up. They overload you with work and create chaos with requiring licensure in 50 states, but do absolutely nothing to help make the process easier. By the way, none of the sups or mgrs are required to get multistate licensure. This is more than a 40, 50 + hour work week. They take advantage of their employees and drain them emotionally. Many of the sups and mgrs do not have bachelors degrees, let alone a masters. The company right now has a good reimbursement for tuition but the managers, if they know about it, don’t promote it and are against it. They have to sign off on it and make it quite difficult. They make a big deal about numbers and productivity and expect you to meet them but they are ultimately in control of your numbers. It is not a good job if you have a family. Of course almost every nurse that walks in the door  has done the backbreaking work of floor nursing and doesn’t  want to go back to that, and so they hear potential to work from home, and think it’s so great, but by the time they get to the point that they may be able to work from home, they don’t even want to be there and quit! Awful company to work for and now I know why insurance cost so much. Aetna wastes so much time on training and restraining because the turnover is high, and they spend a ridiculous amount of money on multistate licensure that has no baring on the quality of a nurse. The administrative assistant is so self absorbed and more focused on her gym time than she is with helping the new hires get situated. Training is a unorganized and unrelated to the job. Don’t waste your time and energy with this job!

job_title: Business Project Program Senior Manager in Hartford, CT
pros: Opportunity to working with some of the brightest, most creative, innovative people in the business.
cons: Tendency for teams to work in tribes/silos.  Individuals work well together...teams not so much.

pros: Smart People, Interesting work, Good Work-Life balance, Great culture, Excellent mission
cons: Very big and bureaucratic, Hard to make decisions because so many people needed to weigh in, Crappy benefits considering it's an insurance company, Don't prioritize personal career development

job_title: Company to Small in Fresno, CA
pros: Decent pay, schedules are good,  cafeteria has good food
cons: If you have family emergency or are sick they don’t care and will fire you. Benefits aren’t great, people steal your food from the refrigerator,

job_title: Long Term Care Case Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Working from home, salary means you are a performance based employee and can not be written up for leaving early or coming in late
cons: Not enough recognition within our department for going above and beyond.  Always putting out the fire and not being prepared for tough times.

pros: There is a great sense of work and life balance.  We are treated with respect and are open to innovative ideas.
cons: It took a long while for deserved promotions to be implemented.  There is not a lot of opportunity for upward movement within our department.

review_title: An excellent learning opportunity in a company with solid values.  Most of the people who work at the company truly care
pros: Values, people, capabilities, autonomy, my direct boss.  Most of the people who work at the company truly care about our customers and the success of the company, and do the right things for the right reasons.
cons:
Ron Williams' retirement
Layoffs
Stress
Constant threat of outsourcing

pros: The company values their employees and career development.  They have very good work-life balance with combination of office time and teleworking.
cons: The company has a very large feel to it.  Many times you feel like just a number, and not an employee.  They have instituted a culture change, it seems to be taking too long, and not grasped by enough employees.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Austin, TX
pros: Great people to work with, love helping members in need.
cons: I was with the company for almost 3 years but was not able to relocate to my home town when my dad had a terminal illness (cancer).

review_title: great company...if you work for the right person

cons: Office politics. Very little training for new employees. So many employees that you are just a number.

review_title: No longer a stable work environment
pros: They have great continuation of education benefits.  The work schedule is flexible enough to create a decent work life balance.
cons: The threat of layoffs are always imminent.   If you are promoted from within you are paid remarkably  less than an outside hire.  The workloads are becoming less and less manageable with each layoff and/or restructuring.

pros: I do not know what pros
cons: Unless you are friends with or related to the right people,  forget it. It's all favoritism.  Benefits are the worst I've ever heard of anywhere. $16,500 out of pocket!  No work life balance.  Management is condescending and should be taught how to be managers and how to have conversations. Executives always hold meetings to talk about how great they are. Computer systems never work and are outdated.

review_title: If you have a better opportunity, go there
