cons: HORRIBLE BENEFITS, pointless prolonged trainings that wont help you once your on the floor, you do the job of 6 DEPARTMENTS yet you are UNDERPAID for just once job. If you want to work here as a temporary oppurtunity then great. But after a while you will see that what your doing there is worth way more at another company. Which is why Aetna constantly loses employees to other insurances. They actually value their employees and pay them properly .

pros: The people I work with. Working from home.

When you WORK FOR THE INSURANCE COMPANY, you should be able to claim your benefits are excellent. That is not the case.

pros: Telework opportunites, technology available and discounts available at various outside vendors

review_title: Hope things have gotten better since I was there!

Decent work life balance

cons: Difficult to obtain large increases in salary once hired - bonuses are sometimes used to compensate for this.  High likelihood of lay-offs yearly - when hired, be sure chosen position is a high-need / in-demand role.

review_title: Great company that any one would be proud to work for!

cons: Difficult to progress in some departments. I found my particular department to be a little top heavy making it difficult for promotion.

pros: Great place to work.  Opportunities to work from home or work in office.  Generous benefits including paid time off and 401K contributions by employer.
cons: Frequent layoffs, only offers employees high deductible health plans for medical insurance.

pros: Great benefits!  Health insurance and dental awesome.  Wish I still worked there but had to move.  Loved my director and team players!
cons: No time off.  Hard to get a break, but paid holidays so that is a plus.  Wish management stuck to their promise.

pros: I have the best co-workers and the health benefits are great. Have a flexible schedule and it's a casual work environment.
cons: High sress job due to having to meet production results.

pros: I pay no premiums for my high deductible HSA medical plan. The health benefits are great. My annual bonus is great.
cons: The annual raise is low even with a satisfactory evaluation. There is a lot of inconsistency with lower management and favoritism.

pros:
The compensation is above-average, the hours are very reasonable for almost all departments.

Occasionally working from home is an option for most employees.
cons: Corporate does very little to show it is invested in the growth of the employees. Discretionary budgets are small or non-existent. Turnover is frequent.

job_title: Senior Account Manager in Houston, TX

cons: Training is severely lacking.  Ability to quickly locate accurate information is extremely difficult.  Internal web resources often contain outdated and incorrect material on products and services and finding answers to healthcare policy questions is challenging.  There is often a need to double and triple check answers to client questions received from internal parties.

pros: Vp ,Manager and Med director are awesome. Co workers and office staff are fun to talk too

review_title: WAH only plus-but changed after Jan. 2017

cons: Low base salaries. Internal promotions only allow up to 10% annual salary. Someone coming from the street would get more. Also, too many layoffs.

cons: No chance for overtime in all departments, benefits are decent but a little high. Wish we had lower deductibles. Rotating shifts.

review_title: Great company for work for, if under a good manager

cons: old fashioned on technology, not the leader in cutting edge technology. bad maternity leave plans, bad insurance to own employees.

pros: Comfortable work conditions. On-site cafeterias, vacation time, voluntary time off without pay, 401k, education assistance, work/life balance assistance, satisfactory, but not great, medical benefit.
cons: Unfortunately the pay is very low. Rarely are bonuses given, internal workings are extremely bureaucratic, and systems/departments cannot communicate together effectively or efficiently. Terrible member experiences especially when joining Aetna.

review_title: Great place to work, but limited growth opportunities
pros: Work and life balance, woman friendly, stable of the job, good vacation leave, wellness programs and the reward is about $1200 for family a year.
cons: minimum job advance opportunities to minorities. Not much of the focus on developing employee professionally. The training is more on Aetnaized.

review_title: Aetna is a great place to work.

cons: Aetna overall - none.  Every big company will have some managers with values that don't fit with the overall culture, however.

job_title: QA Project Manager in Hartford, CT
pros: ample opportunities to work and gain experience, very fast paced, lots of good resources available to employees (internal training, various perks)
cons: too aggressive with cost cutting initiatives, management not true to values preached, a bit politically charged and vision frequently changes

review_title: Case management RN dedicated plan sponser ITC model
pros: Computer educational training skill opportunities. Opportunities to learn case management and insurance side of business and financial effects to insurance business.
cons: Salaried position. Management Lies in interview process to multiple RN's. They say they are flexible but work load is that of a 50 hour week. Understaffed currently as they have taken on 44 extra accounts and are understaffed by at least 25 nurses for the new business. They say they value the Aetna core values such as integrity yet show you none. They are not giving bonuses for 2014 year till April 2015 clearly to assess the first quarter finances of 2015. They say you have adequate training period time yet you are thrown to task before you have completed training. Supervisors have agenda only for self and do not advocate for over worked RN case manager staff. Your bonus won't even cover the multiple overtime hours that you will slave over your computer to meet the demands and requirements in place. You are required to pick up the work of other coworkers if they slack off, call out sick and have pto. This is in addition to your 10 load of work task.  The benefits for Aetna employees is a rip off and they are capitalizing off their own employees. 4500$ deductibles for single young person plan.  Promotions are given to mediocre employees without 4 year nurse degrees or any management training skills. Poor work life balance.

pros: This is a friendly environment. Working here provides work-life balance.
cons: The compensation is low for what they expect of you. Leadership needs to be more hands on. They also need a better way to troubleshoot computer problems. Growth potential in certain departments is lacking.

pros: Telecommute positions are the norm and supported, offering great work/life balance. As a new manager to the company, they offer great resources and technology tools to help me do my job.
cons: You will work hard but the work is rewarding.

pros: Benefits are very good.  Working on the business side is more secure.  Great telecommute options available.
cons: Technical side is downsizing, out sourcing and pushing more work off shore.  Not able to keep up with changing market place.

pros: PTO, work at home, wellness
cons: management!  There is a lot of micro management.  Bullying is a big problem by a few female managers and it is just too darn bad that no one does a darn thing about it.  Karma!

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Fresno, CA
pros: Good starting pay, decent benefits
cons: Poor management with very little opportunity for advancement.  Reactive management style as opposed to listening to the rank and file about what needs fixing.  Although they want you to believe your opinions and suggestions for a better work place environment matter, they really don't.   It's all about the bottom dollar.......typical corporate environment.  Just a number......

pros: There is a lot of opportunity for growth within the company. Overall great working enviroment. Despite the sometimes heavy work load during busy periods, management does a good job showing their appreciation for their staff
cons: Doesn't always feel like there is enough staffing ready for peak periods in the call center. Sometimes the hiring process  seems rushed, often times beginning the hiring process just 3 weeks prior to the start dates.

pros: Locally, I liked the people I worked with. Most directors/managers were very cool people with the exception of a few. Work from home options and were very flexible when I had some difficult home situations.
cons:
I don't really know what happened to this company but it breaks my heart. I worked there 7 years and the first 6 were great, with the exception of their health insurance which led me to file bankruptcy.  At this point, I strongly recommend staying far away from Aetna and I never thought I'd say that. It honestly kills me. Advancement is a joke, get a better job within the company and your pay will not increase to reflect it. There are 2 ways to make more money at Aetna. 1. Quit and then go back, lose seniority but potentially higher pay upon returning. Or 2. Say you're going to quit and see if there's a retention offer. You'd think that working hard and keeping your head down would count for something, it absolutely doesn't. 

LTD is a mess, with directors (managers new title that Aetna gave them to pay them more, think about that one) have no actual experience doing the job of their subordinates and don't know how much time it takes to process claims. Most DBMs simply push out tasks to appear timely when in fact they are far behind in their work. This is done out of necessity. Scope of job regularly expands to cover other departments functions with no compensation raise. Directors and above will pretend everything is ok when the sustainability of the process and workload is questioned, and will make you feel that you are the problem.  There's talk of raises to actually pay employees at market level however this includes making them exempt. Here's what will happen: pay will increase and then employees will be expected to work tons of OT thus bringing their actual compensation lower than before. 

The insurance is abysmal and a great example of what happens when there's no competition. Hey Aetna, why not pay your employees with vouchers to the company store? I knew several people in financial turmoil due to medical bills. Here was my checklist when considering treatment: am I dying? If not, then just suffer through it because otherwise it was thousands of dollars in medical bills. This is what the insurance company does to their employees and you have Bertolini who acts empathetic because he broke his neck once and had to go through some difficulties. Hey Bert, offering the worst benefits I've ever seen to your employees and not paying them at market level isn't empathetic, your actions do not match your words, sir. 

Compensation reviews are a joke. You can be rated 1 - 5. Hope you like the number 3 because rarely is anyone rated above this, guess why. Raises have been around 1%. Employees haven't left because they're too overworked to look around. Do not get mired in this mess. STANDARD EMPLOYEES: Look elsewhere, Aetna is a wolf in sheep's clothing. I promise you. Aetna is doing very well financially and this success is not shared with employees. These are not petty complaints here, all above relates to your financial and physical well-being. I quit my job with absolutely nothing lined up. That's how bad it truly is.

pros: The work life balance is great. There are really nice people within the company. Depending on your division you have tons of ownership over your role.
cons: It's a large matrix company and sometimes it's hard to find the answer you need. Enterprise leadership strives for innovation where as local leaders like to keep things status quo.

pros: Decent salary.  Bonuses are iffy. LTI are now gone. I really can't think of any other positives and GD requires 20 words on here

They just took away director level Long Term Incentives while the balance sheet shows top levels getting rich.  4 jobs for every one person. If you like working at 2 am, this is the place for you.....

review_title: IT Program and Project Managers - avoid working here
job_title: IT Program Manager in Belo Horizonte, Minas Gerais
pros:
Pay is on par with industry standard.
Flexible with work at home options
Mark Bertolini is truly an inspiring leader - doesn't trickle to the IT Program Delivery department
cons:
No on boarding for new employees - this was a disaster with the Coventry integration.  

The Aetna project management methodology is massive in the amount of deliverables and processes , but they eliminated the majority of coaches so you are on your own to figure it out.

Directors are not leaders nor are they emotionally intelligent.  They are rewarded for delivering , but no incentive to mentor or inspire their teams.  PM's are just bodies to be placed with no regard for career aspirations.  Those discussions do not happen

There are some particularly unpleasant people in leadership positions - and bullying is rampant.  HR is outsourced and it's not an option as I've heard of retaliation from those that did go that route

The anonymous employee survey that should root out problem areas has the fatal flaw of being tied to the all employees scorecard. So if you are actually honest - your bonus is impacted.  I don't know if this is part of why Bertolini has allowed the same IT leaders to remain and just demoralize the organization or perhaps IT is just simply not valued

review_title: Ok, but dont expect a promotion regardless of how talented or good you are.
pros: Flexible work arrangments. Good supervisors, but middle and upper management dont have any idea of what they are doing. Decent pay.
cons: Constant threat of layoffs. Benefits are reduced each year. No chance of advancement. Very little chance of receiving a bonus.

review_title: Great benefits & resources available. Strict policies, somewhat big brotherish.
pros: Lots of programs available to employees, great benefits, very health & wellness driven. Great training.
cons: Very strict policies, and quite a "clock puncher" attitude from most employees in mid level positions or lower.

review_title: Employees paying price for lack of planning
pros: It's a job. Could be worse. Some niches look comfy. Unlike flat organizations, middle management who do nothing but go to meetings and inhibit communication between top brass and grunts are not only tolerated, but encouraged, as it makes upper management's life much easier.
cons:
Doing more with less has become something of a fetish. Whereas at one time a problem would be solved by throwing bodies at it, currently they just throw unpaid overtime by exempt employees at it. Spending money on computer systems upgrades is out of the question. 

Departmental management have come to the point where they thank employees for all the hard work last year, then promise them even more as the reward. You're lucky if you don't throw away vacation days at the end of the year that you can't carry over. Not having taken a vacation or even a long weekend in the past year is considered a good thing. 

Nothing much works at any level, and nothing much is fixed. More workers are thrown to work around  the problem as a permanent bandaid. Aetna is in the middle of yet another attempt to fix the problems without actually changing anything, with a culture change initiative. It won't work. In spite of all the modern trappings and conversion to health insurance, this is still basically the same insurance company it was a century ago, when workers had to be seated at their desks from one bell to the next, or waited at the edge of the roped off carpeted areas for the godlike company officers to summon them into the divine presence.

Employees are entirely at the mercy of their supervisors. HR is powerless to intercede in even the most obvious cases of mistreatment if nothing actually illegal is going on. 

Now that they've purchased Coventry, it's obvious from their history that there will be layoffs, and they will come from the Aetna side.

review_title: Overall very good, especially under Ron Williams inspiring leadership.
pros: You will get good experience.
cons: Management plays favorites...your career advancement doesn't depend on how smart you are or how hard you work...it depends on who likes you.  Lots of in-fighting and dysfunctional leadership.

review_title: Would not recommend this company to anyone, friend or not.
pros: Competitive salary to start, dangles ideas of advancement opportunities, bonus opportunities, overtime, telework, fair work environment, equal opportunity employer...all to get you in the door. Casual dress code is a huge plus.
cons: It's not what you know, it's who you know and who likes you with this company that will determine how far you will go and what jobs you will advance to that you apply for or if you even keep your job. If you go in and mind your own business and do your job, 99% of the time, you won't be favorited. Valid complaints to immediate supervisors that should be taken serious are swept under the carpet and the employee is told that they are "dealt with" when they are not. Concerns are commented back with smart remarks and comments. Retaliation is a huge fear with this company. If you speak up, you may just find yourself getting fire or laid off because they don't like the wrong things coming to light. If you don't fit in, you will find yourself very quickly pushed to the outter circle, supervisor included. We are understaffed and overworked and when we bring it up how stressed out we are, we are told to do more or work overtime or that we aren't a team player. The department doesn't seem to care for our personal well being or health when it comes down to crunching the numbers. It's do do do, but don't Ask questions or for help to get stuff done quickly, instead, send off your question and wait a day or two for an answer. Employees are not compensated well for the amount of work that they do. There has been no cost of living increase in many years. The benefits come with such a high deductible that If you have to use it, you better make sure you get everything done with in one year to make it worth it. You have to tell the customer service reps that handle employee benefits what to do and how to do something when you call them because they have now clue. The CEO gets huge raises and the employees get a small lunch tote for a milestone anniversary gift. I will ask that unless you take this job as a stepping stone to a much bigger and better career, because it works with a school schedule, please do not get sucked into the Aetna environment. Not only is it harmful to your stress levels, it's harmful to your personal life as well.

review_title: I had a long career there. They are an excellent company

cons:
Micromanagement
Antiquated systems, and TOO MANY SYSTEMS that don't even talk to each other. I have to log into no less than ten systems a day to do my job. They are slow and don't work half the time
OUTSOURCING
Incompetent management
Unreasonable production metrics
Every good program rolled out comes with multiple "workflows" that are extremely time consuming, frustrating and seem to be in place to DISCOURAGE staff to utilize them (SWOB)
Extremely siloed...Don't bother trying to talk to another department, it's very much frowned upon.
Pay is NOT based on performance but some mysterious number they have; you can get 'salary capped' and not get a raise ever again
I could go on and on and on...

review_title: Someone will always want health insurance

review_title: Not enough money to deal with my boss' level of insanity

cons: Management in the department I worked for a "clique" and if they did not like you for any reason (even made up reasons), you were pushed out of your position. I watched it happened 4 times in 1 year.

review_title: Good Company that offers a lot of opportunity and good work life balance
job_title: Medical Economics Analyst in Hartford, CT
pros: Hartford Campus is great. Good work life balance. Great atmosphere and opportunity to move within company. Easy to network. Gym facilities are great. Great benefits (especially health/fitness wise).
cons: Reorganizations happen all the time so you may have new managers/teammates all the time. Also causes workload to fluctuate. Pay could be better.

pros:
Benefits decent with their wellness incentives that help somewhat offset the high deductible plans. As long as you don't need to use your medical insurance it's not that expensive.

They say the right things about their culture and service - too bad it's not real.

They do have a lot of charitable works in the communities that are nice. Again, it's public facing and a different story inside the walls about how charitable they are to their employees.
cons:
When you have to bring body guards to visit one of your facilities and meet your staff but none of your employees can come near you - you may have an ego problem. Mark B. has forgotten what real people do for a living and what it means to have to work for your paycheck and health care.  His employees can't speak to him so how can he speak about what it's like to be a normal person living paycheck to paycheck paying their medical bills? He knows nothing of the "common man" from his ivory tower making more in 2 minutes than most of this employees make in a year.

The management they keep in place is poor. LOTS of micromanagement extreme style and poor leadership, decision makers in place. Knee jerk reactions and finger pointing at every turn.  You will not have a chance to figure out a problem and present solutions without 5 layers of management on your back directing you what to do and say/not-say.

 VERY low morale and lack of caring who gets stepped on as someone climbs over you to go higher. If you're not part of the favorites you won't ever move up or out of your dept.  Your supervisor can block any application to another team/department simply because they don't like you.

Pay increases annually are very low. Bonuses have been decreasing as well.  

Lots of working on weekends, holidays, long nights for no thank you or reward. 

It is a shame to see such a historical company go to CVS and it be run the way it is by leaders who are not in touch with doing what is right by their employees. Maybe CVS can bring that to this company.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Akron, OH
pros: Work from home. Long training period.
cons: Unrealistic expectations regarding number of required engaged members in case management programs.

pros: great people to work with

review_title: Be prepared to sit with no tasks to complete frequently

cons: Training is 20 weeks no exceptions, occurrences are received for even just a  minute tardy whether you call ahead to advise of circumstances, plan in advance time off needed for doctor appointment, dental,childcare, etc. Every time you turn around you are getting an occurrence and feels like you are always in trouble.

pros: Great environment and culture. Perks of the job are too many to count.

pros: They have very good work-life balance with combination of office time and teleworking. Also the company encourages and motivates employees for their health/wellness with an incentive system and provides variety of health programs.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Fresno, CA
pros: Great environment to work in. Positive people and lot of room to progress with your career. Good benefits and decent pay depending on your position
cons: There really aren't many cons some positions seem to get micromanage a bit but that's about it. There is also a cafeteria so you will gain some weight

pros: Company itself seemed okay in other orgs. Cafe is great. Gym is nice. The atrium building gets a lot of light though it's noisy because of the lack of cube walls and bull pen style. Work from home is nice. PTO is fair.
cons: Where to start? Data Science is a nightmare. There is no organization. People with the keys to the big data environment have little technical aptitude and the mistaken impression of otherwise. Leadership is afraid to make decisions and not empowered to do so anyway. As a result individual contributers are constantly changing direction based on panicked leaders trying to appease an unappeasable senior leadership. The constant change of direction means nothing gets done and if it does it's hacked together. Morale is so low they are hemorrhaging talent monthly. HR has tried to rope unknowing new hires in with decent starting salary and meager sign on bonuses or retention bonuses with overly aggressive clawbacks hoping you can't afford to leave. Don't be fooled by hype about a start up like culture, it's a racket. The only parallel to Google is the long hours and cut throat vibe.  Expect to be belittled in front of your peers by leaders. Expect to be sold on a job description and then have your job reassigned to where ever they need a warm body. Its 24/7 confusion with no strategy no direction and no ability to even describe what success looks like. For all the money invested I haven't seen anything notable produced. The one product that had legs they smothered like an unwanted kitten with their incompetence. The org had so much potential, squandered. Anyone with any talent in this competitive industry can find a better gig for better money and less chest pain at night. YMMV but Buyer Beware.

job_title: Senior Informatics Analyst in Hartford, CT
pros: It is a huge company, generally various resources fly in, you got a chance to meet people from IBM, The Hortonworks, CA technologist. cons:
1) wage is way below national average for an engineer: every time feel shamed when talking about this with my school peers

2) No technique and therefore it looks bad on your resume for an engineer: it is a world of business, no dedication to technology. people talks and plays about fancy tech words and that is it. 

3) Barely transparency on higher level management

4) Sometimes you feel this company is just trying to take every possible advantage of you: as some pretty famous manager in DS department, who humiliates his team on their professional level and asks to work overtime because that is what "California High Tech Companies" do and I am doing this to spur you to a real career summit, so disregard how much they get paid and how much you get paid. Overtime payment, is there such a thing on the world?

5) eventually it is a healthcare company, which exports most of IT work to Infosys, Accenture consulting firms for budget control, the only way here to be successful is to get into management population. You will figure out the huge gap in terms of base salary between management and non-management population. Higher education almost means nothing unless it is a MBA. Cheap labor is always easy to find, outsourcing is the fact already! Descent engineering work is not appreciated but pushing young and inexperienced people to work overtime, such fantastic management skill, is highly welcomed!! It is NO GOOD for perhaps every type of engineer but would be a wonderland for young, ambitious and aggressive business young folks, best luck on my colleagues' probability of success!
